page.syntax: C Result = varToJSON(* var [,L flagSpecialTags [,L flagCondense [,C indent [,L flagQuotesOnPropNames [,L flagHonorNulls ]]]]])

argument.name: flagSpecialTags
argument.description: (optional) Set to .T. to use {...} tags; defaults to .F.

argument.name: flagCondense
argument.description: (optional) Set to .T. to remove pretty formatting

argument.name: indent
argument.description: (optional) Set to some number of spaces for indented formatting

argument.name: flagQuotesOnPropNames
argument.description: (optional) Set to .T. to quote property names

page.description: Converts an Xbasic variable to a JSON representation.

discussion.p: The varToJSON() function converts an Xbasic variable to a JSON representation. If flagSpecialTags is .t. then you can use {function} and optional {functionArguments:var1,var2} in a property value to encode as a function. You can also use {Javascript} for arbitrary Javascript. With varToJSON vs varToJSONStandard the difference is that JSONStandard uses double quotes while varToJSON assumes single quotes. The varToJSONStandard() function is preferred.

section.description: Try this in an interactive session.

description.p: 1. We use {functionarguments:arg1,arg2,arg3} to specify arguments for a functions
2. We demonstrate how xbasic property arrays translate to js arrays of object literals
3. We demonstrate how the helper function a5_json_prep() removes properties with blank values (e.g. p.city).

section.example:
dim p as p dim p.children[0] as p
p.name = "selwyn" p.surname = "{function}alert('onchange')" p.children[].name = "{function}alert('onclick')" p.children[..].age = 4 p.children[].name = "Joe" p.children[..].age = 6 p.city = "Smith"
p.myfunc = "Emma"+\ "Zoe"
a5_JSON_Prep(p) showvar(varToJSON(p,.t.))
